docs.abstract: Gen Peter Pace says he urged his Chinese counterparts to provide more information about aims of their military buildup; calls meetings in Beijing encouraging, but says he did not get concrete answers; says China's recent test of antisatellite weapon sent confusing message to world about its military intentions, but US and China are slowly building stronger military-to-military ties (M)

headline.main: Head of Joint Chiefs Calls China's Military Aims Unclear

docs.snippet: Gen. Peter Pace said he urged his Chinese counterparts to provide more information about the aims of their military buildup.
docs.lead_paragraph: China's recent test of an antisatellite weapon sent a confusing message to the world about its military intentions, but the United States and China are slowly building stronger military-to-military ties, the top-ranking United States military officer said Friday. Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said he urged his Chinese counterparts in meetings on Thursday and Friday to provide more information about the aims of their military buildup. He called the meetings ''encouraging,'' but said he did not get concrete answers.

docs.abstract: Mike Meyer article on shops and cafes in Beijing's historic lane district; photos (S)
docs.snippet: As the city prepares for the 2008 Summer Olympics, Beijing’s historic lanes, or hutongs, are disappearing in a dust cloud of new construction.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the city prepares for the 2008 Summer Olympics, Beijing's historic lanes, or hutongs, are disappearing in a dust cloud of new construction. But South Gong and Drum Lane (Nan Luoguxiang) is an exception. Near the central lakes, the 700-year-old hutong is a bit of authentic bohemia in an otherwise Starbucks-saturated central city. Mike Meyer

docs.abstract: Some experts question security at Hong Kong horse racing tracks, which will be used for 2008 Beijing Olympics, after finding dart-shooting mechanism embedded in turf; photos (M)

headline.main: Security for 2008 Olympic Equestrian Events Is Questioned

docs.snippet: A mechanism rigged to fire tiny darts into the bellies of horses was found buried in the turf at the Happy Valley Racecourse.
docs.lead_paragraph: It was a device worthy of Rube Goldberg, or perhaps Wile E. Coyote. A remote-controlled mechanism with a dozen launching tubes was found buried in the turf at Hong Kong's most famous horse racing track last week; it was rigged with compressed air to fire tiny, liquid-filled darts into the bellies of horses at the starting gate. No horses were injured because the supervisor at the Happy Valley Racecourse, where horses have been racing since 1846, noticed something on the turf before racing started Wednesday. He discovered the mechanism concealed by grass-colored tape and called in a police bomb squad to remove it.

docs.abstract: Aric Chen travel article on influx of high-profile galleries that is turning Caochangdi Village in Beijing's northeast district into contemporary art scene; photo; map (M)

headline.main: A New Frontier for Chinese Art

docs.snippet: An influx of high-profile galleries are turning Caochangdi Village, a quiet, birch- and pine-lined enclave, into an artistic hotbed.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEVEN years ago, the pre-eminent Chinese artist Ai Weiwei made a bold move to the outskirts of Beijing. In an area called Caochangdi Village, by the Fifth Ring Road in the city's northeast, he designed a compound for himself, some friends and a gallery called China Art Archives and Warehouse. For a while, they were left alone. ''We all thought they were cuckoo,'' said Meg Maggio, a prominent contemporary art dealer in Beijing. ''It was basically the countryside -- really far away.''

docs.abstract: Diplomatic Memo: China's decision to pressure Sudan about violence in Darfur, after years of protecting that government, can be traced to campaign to boycott 2009 Olympic Games in Beijing; Mia Farrow, good-will ambassador for United Nations Children's Fund, started campaign to label Games in Beijing 'Genocide Olympics' and called on corporate sponsors to publicly exhort China to do something about Darfur; she challenged Steven Spielberg, artistic advisor to China for Games, to add his voice, prompting Spielberg to send letter to Pres Hu Jintao of China asking him to use his influence to stop killings in Darfur; senior Chinese official, Zhai Jun, recently traveled to Sudan to push government there to accept UN peacekeeping force, and then visited Darfur refugee camps; turnaround in China's policy serves as classic study of how pressure campaign, aimed to strike Beijing in vulnerable spot at vulnerable time, could accomplish what years of diplomacy could not; photo (M)

headline.main: Darfur Collides With Olympics, And China Yields

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.snippet: Mia Farrow and Steven Spielberg are involved in an effort to pressure China to stop protecting Sudan’s government.
docs.lead_paragraph: For the past two years, China has protected the Sudanese government as the United States and Britain have pushed for United Nations Security Council sanctions against Sudan for the violence in Darfur. But in the past week, strange things have happened. A senior Chinese official, Zhai Jun, traveled to Sudan to push the Sudanese government to accept a United Nations peacekeeping force. Mr. Zhai even went all the way to Darfur and toured three refugee camps, a rare event for a high-ranking official from China, which has extensive business and oil ties to Sudan and generally avoids telling other countries how to conduct their internal affairs.

docs.abstract: Brooklyn tourist Kellie Kvern comments on revisiting, after decade, old quarter of Beijing that is being demolished; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Kellie Kvern, 35, from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, exploring an old quarter of Beijing in the process of being demolished: ''I went back to Beijing for three weeks; I had lived there for three years as a student and as a teacher of English. I hadn't been
docs.lead_paragraph: Kellie Kvern, 35, from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, exploring an old quarter of Beijing in the process of being demolished: ''I went back to Beijing for three weeks; I had lived there for three years as a student and as a teacher of English. I hadn't been back in 10 years, so this trip was just to see the city again. It's pretty common that these homes are going down to make way for new stuff. We met a family that was still living in that neighborhood, and they invited us into their house to have lunch. I can't imagine that they were thrilled about the demolition, but we didn't have any conversations about it. Everything just changes so fast there. I brought a friend of mine from New York who had never been, and she and I were in the same boat. Going back after 10 years was really like going to the city for the first time.'' As told to Austin Considine

docs.abstract: Intel plans to announce number of technology advances at Intel Developers Forum in Beijing, China, including initiative that could introduce new class of wireless hand-held computers (M)

headline.main: Intel Seen Using China Forum To Detail Plans on Hand-Helds

docs.snippet: A number of technology advances will be announced, including an initiative that could give rise to a new class of wireless hand-held computers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Intel is planning to announce a number of technology advances this week at a conference in Beijing, including an initiative that could give rise to a new class of wireless hand-held computers, according to several people close to the efforts. The conference, the Intel Developer Forum, is held three times a year, and its convening in China underscores the growing significance of the Chinese market in the computer industry. Last month, Intel announced that it would build its first chip-making factory in China.

docs.abstract: David J Scheffer letter, prompted by April 13 article on China's decision to pressure Sudan about violence in Darfur, says China's tardy efforts are solely cosmetic diplomacy; urges sports fans to boycott 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing

headline.main: China and Darfur: Time for Pressure

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Darfur Collides With Olympics, and China Yields'' (Diplomatic Memo, front page, April 13):
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Darfur Collides With Olympics, and China Yields'' (Diplomatic Memo, front page, April 13):

docs.abstract: Chinese leaders regard choice of Beijing as host of 2008 Summer Olympics as milestone event to showcase China to world; for Beijing officials, it is also cause for civic anxiety; they worry about some local habits, and have launched citywide campaign to try to curb public spitting, discourage public cursing and littering and also promote lining up; city is even holding monthly 'Queuing Day'; some Communist Party officials recommend heavy fines for those who spit, cut ahead in line or use foul language; photo (M)

headline.main: No Spitting on the Road to Olympic Glory, Beijing Says

docs.snippet: Citywide campaigns are trying to improve the public awareness of manners ahead of the 2008 Summer Olympics.
docs.lead_paragraph: For all the expectations and civic pride that Beijing has attached to being the host of the 2008 Summer Olympics, the event is a source of civic anxiety, too. What if traffic is terrible? What if the weather is bad? These are worries for any host city, but Beijing also has a few more: What if foreign visitors are forced to navigate a minefield of saliva left by local pedestrians spitting on sidewalks? What if lines at Olympic events dissolve into scrums as local residents jump to the head of pack? What if Chinese fans serenade rival teams with the guttural, unprintable ''Beijing curse''?

docs.abstract: Abortion in China has been associated with married women complying with country's one-child policy, but as society has rapidly changed, so has face of abortion; unmarried women, including teenagers, are now having rising number of abortions, and even constitute majority of cases in Shanghai and parts of Beijing; health experts say that many of these women are having multiple abortions; photos (M)

headline.main: Today's Face of Abortion in China Is a Young, Unmarried Woman

docs.snippet: Abortion is no longer just associated with married women complying with the country’s one-child policy.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY; Lin Yang contributed

docs.lead_paragraph: At an abortion clinic in this seaside city, a young woman sat in the recovery room with an IV drip in one hand and a cellphone in the other. She was 22 and worked as a nurse. Her boyfriend, an information technology specialist, sat nearby. They both knew the routine: It was her second abortion in 18 months. In the waiting room, a few other unmarried couples watched a DVD of a hit Chinese movie until they were called. The clinic, one of the few in China that focuses on reproductive health for single women, performed 65 abortions in March. Of those women, 42 were having at least their second abortion. One woman had her sixth.
